title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine or ‘the dead month’.   or Saint Bride’s Day. This falls in with ‘Candlemas’ on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke’s Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‘Quarter-days’ marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‘Bridgets’, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‘Bridget of Kildare’ in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‘Bride’s little fosterling’.’ . ‘Bride’s Day, the birthday of spring’. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‘The serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride’s Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride’s mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.’ The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‘hymn’ makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride’s Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‘Coming Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends’ and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup Mànran.The show will be Donnie’s first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree. The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland’s top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year’s Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‘one of the best boutique festivals in the country’, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be Mànran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled ÙRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‘Gaelic Singer of the Year’ at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.Mànran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for Mànran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: island couple fly the flag for skye in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineA Skye couple who are embarking on a trip of a letime in Antarctica have proudly flown the official island flag this week while camping at the earth#s southernmost continent.Melanie and Bob Mossfrom Camastianavaig, near Portree, left the island on th January in the first leg of an epic journey which saw them arrive late last week at the landmass which is almost wholly ice-covered, spans . million kilometres, and is located more than , miles south of Skye.Speaking to the Free Press from their camp at Kerr Point, Melanie detailed her and Bob#s incredible voyage so far.She said: #On the th January we flew to Santiago, Chile and arrived in mid-morning of the th. We stayed in quarantine overnight . On the th we flew from Santiago south to Punta Arenas at the tip of Chile to meet our ship.#Melanie and Bob are sailing on the MS Roald Amundsen which is a Hybrid powered expedition ship owned by the Norwegian company Hurtigruten.#We are at sea for  days in total, exploring the Antarctic Peninsula,# she said.#We aren#t exactly known for traditional beach holidays on the Costas, so this voyage was perfect for us. Going to rarely visited places at the end of the earth, to see things only a few other people have ever seen.“It also helps I love penguins.”Melanie said that by sailing by expedition ship, they had the opportunity to explore remote parts of Antarctica on foot and from small zodiac boats, getting close to nature and the beautul wilderness.She added: #We are one of the very few passenger ships to get below the Antarctic Circle this season, so it was a privilege to spend three days down there. The photo of me holding the flag on the balcony below the Antarctic Circle at .° south.#Earlier this week, Melanie alerted the Free Press about their adventure asking: #@WHFP do you know how far any of the fantastic new Skye Flags have travelled  Ours left Camustianavaig with us last month and crossed the Antarctic Circle to ° South and last night we camped with it at Kerr Point Antarctica ° South.#Melanie explained: #I took the flag as it hangs in my ‘den’ at home and when I was researching the trip it was always catching my eye.#It dawned on me one day that I#d be travelling further south than Skye is north and I should take the flag with us. When Bob and I got the opportunity to camp at Kerr Point ° south we just had to fly the flag proudly.”She added: #Only  guests had the opportunity to camp the night in Antarctica, so we were very lucky. Our camp neighbours were from Germany and asked us about the flag as they did not recognise it. We were very proud to explain where we came from and how new the flag is to the Isle of Skye.#I also work seasonally as an instructor at ACE Target Sports, Portree and we have photos of playing cards customers have won at ACE and taken with them around the world. I have taken a couple of ACE#S with me, taken photos and sent them back to Mattto add to the album! So, we are flying the flag for ACE as well.#Melanie and Bob are due to arrive back on Skye next Wednesday #All in all, an epic trip, never to be forgotten and full of amazing memories. Even the eye-wateringly cold Antarctic plunges we have both done down here!# she addedThe couple#s flying of the Skye standard will no doubt be a proud moment for young islander Calum Alasdair Munro from Kilmuir. The youngster’s design was selected as the official flag following a competition which lasted  months, attracted  entries and received more than , public votes.Calum Alasdair raised the flag at an official and socially distant unfurling ceremony at the Nicolson memorial in August .

title: centenary sailor dolan caps his 100th birthday in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineA resident in An Acarsaid care home in Broadford, Skye, ‘Dolan’ as he is known, was asked by staff what he wanted for his special birthday He was proud to wear his answer at Armadale Pier, where he was greeted on the MV Loch Nevis by master and fellow Lewisman Iain Mackenzie, who lives in Kyleakin.As well as the cap, Dolan was also given a bag of CalMac goodies. February  at Flesherin, Point, Dolan worked with his dad making Harris Tweed before getting an apprenticeship with a bakery in Stornoway.However, his ambition was always to join the Merchant Navy, which he did in  in Glasgow.Not long after, he joined the crew of the British-India ship SS Manela which sailed to South Africa during World War Two.Dolan said: “I also went to America, Canada and Australia while at sea and could be away for up to two years at a time, but it was always great to get on the boat in Glasgow and head home to Lewis.“I ed to Lewis for a time after the war and spent many happy years living with my sister Mary Ann down in Back. I loved going down to the pier and watching the ferries come and go when we went to town, many a journey I enjoyed with CalMac.#I have a small picture of the #Sulivan# in my room # the sea and boats have always given me so much joy.”Master Mackenzie added: “It was a pleasure to help Dolan mark his special birthday, we were delighted to welcome him on board.#He is a really interesting character who has travelled the world, and me and the crew were privileged to talk to him and listen to his wonderful stories.#I am from Aird, a nearby village in Point, and it was my pleasure to present the hat and goodies to a fellow rubhach.”Last Sunday , Dolan enjoyed his birthday party in An Acarsaid, surrounded by family and friends and delighted members of staff. The Lord Lieutenant of Ross and Cromarty, Joanie Whiteford, also visited as Dolan received his card from the Queen.Care home manager Margaret Mackinnon told the Free Press it is a pleasure to have Dolan staying in An Acarsaid.“He loves good banter and is keen on his music,” she added. “He plays the mouth organ and the piano and especially loves listening and dancing to ceilidh music. He also loves listening to the accordion.#He is a huge character with us here at An Acarsaid and has a quiet, happy outlook on le.#He enjoys his Golden Virginia smokes and a nice dram. Dolan participates in all our activities and remains a very competitive dominoes player. He loves to win and is loved by all.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220214news56 of ni pet owners would ditch their partners for their pets
story: Men have been warned to be on their best behaviour on Valentine’s Day or face a visit to the dog house, according to a survey of pet owners and their relationships. Women are more likely to ditch their partner than their pet, found a poll for nationwide pet retailer Jollyes. Asked about their relationship with their partner and their pet and which one they would ditch first,  per cent said they would ditch their partner against  per cent who would ditch their pet. Men were more loyal to their partners, with  per cent saying they would ditch their pet and  per cent saying they would ditch their partner. Overall,  per cent would ditch their partner first and  per cent said the pet would go first. The study was carried out by Jollyes to gauge humans’ attitudes to romance and relationships as it launches the search on social media for a canine couple to take part in a romantic dinner for two at its doggy dates diner, “C’est Jollyes”, open for one day only on  February at its Runcorn store in Cheshire . Two dogs will get the chance to enjoy a three course dinner featuring a menu from Jollyes Artisan Lestage range including angus beef with sweet potato, venison and salmon, and duck with sweet potato. The survey showed some big dferences in attitudes to pets and partners around the UK. People in North East England were more likely to ditch their partnerover their pet, followed by London , Northern Ireland , South West . [See table in editor’s notes below for regional breakdown.] Owners were asked what they loved most about their pets, with loyalty, unconditional love, loving nature, affection and a warm heart among the qualities cited. No matter how much love an animal gives, most pet ownerswould prefer a romantic Valentine’s night with their partner than one spent with their pet. Of male respondents,  per cent chose a night with their partner, compared with  per cent of female respondents. The figures were broadly similar across the country. Among the other popular traits cited by pet owners were: “they are so loyal and loving. And cute!” “unconditional love and loyalty” “they comfort me when I’m feeling blue” “doesnt argue or answer back” “they always cheer me up” “waggy tail and warm heart” and “her loving nature, always there for me when I need her”. One said: “Sometimes playful, sometimes cuddly, intelligent, independent, sometimes dangerous. All rather like my partner really.” Not everyone was totally enamoured with their pet. One said: “Nothing, it hates me, only loves my we”. And not all pets’ traits would make for a romantic night out – one said: “hassle free”, another said “doesn’t answer back” and one said “it’s a tortoise and he’s as indferent to use as we are to him”. Phil Turner-Naylor, head of marketing at Jollyes, said: “We’re known as a nation of animal lovers and this goes to prove it. When it comes to relationships, a lot people would choose their pet over their partner. “The good news for romantics though is that a big majority choose people over pets. What it does show, especially for men, is that partners have to work hard to keep the romance going or they might find themselves in the dog house. Women are looking for a romantic night with their partner on Valentine’s, butthe men don’t get it right, they had better watch out.”

title: ballymena man wins 150 000 cash and car prize
story: A Ballymena man got the surprise of a letime when he scooped a six figure cash and car prize including a brand new Range Rover thanks to leading online competitions company BOTB.Having booked an Easter getaway in Spain to recover from COVID-, Wesley McLernon almost changed his mind about doing his weekly BOTB entry. But the -year-old found himself thanking his lucky stars he went ahead when BOTB presenter Christian Williams turned up on his doorstep to deliver the prize of a letime. Christian was there to tell Wesley that he had won a pound, Range Rover PE Autobiography with pound, cash stuffed in the boot. “This is unreal, I’ve never won anything in my le – I think I need a stf drink!” said an astonished Wesley, who lives with his we Elinor and has a -year-old daughter Callendar. EASTER BREAK“I have had a dficult couple of years and also got COVID four weeks ago, so I booked an Easter break in Spain. So I did wonder whether to enter BOTB like I normally do. I am very glad I did now.” The Range Rover boasts a  Torque hybrid engine with bhp under the bonnet. But with the pound, cash stuffed in the boot, it means Wesley will have a ‘pretty good pension pot’, too. “This money will go towards my mortgage, pay off a few bills and give me a pretty good pension pot for the future,” he added. “Thank you so much BOTB!” BOTB hands over the keys to two stunning cars each week as well as a lestyle prize. Other recent winners have bagged pound, in cash, a quad bike and a gaming tech bundle. The company, listed on the stock market, was founded by William Hindmarch in  and has given away more than poundm worth of cars so far. Christian, who surprises winners all over the country every week, said: “Wesley’s story is a truly heartwarming one. He’d booked his family a holiday in Spain after a dficult time so his BOTB win couldn’t have come at a better time – I am delighted for him.” To see Wesley’s shock reaction alongside a host of other lucky winners, just google for BOTB.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220217news1 700 people apply for a life less ordinary with stena line
story: Ferry company Stena Line has been overwhelmed with the positive response from the public to its recent recruitment campaign ‘A Le Less Ordinary’, which aims to fill  vacant positions onboard its Irish Sea ferries. , applications were received from people across the UK and Republic of Ireland. The campaign promoted the unique nature of le onboard, with % time-off providing the perfect work-le balance for people wanting to live and work onboard for either a one or two-week sht and then spend equal time off. The positions available are part of the Onboard Sales and Servicesteam, with vacancies for service assistants and chefs. With January being the traditional time of the year when many people look for a new career, Stena Line had hoped for a favourable response but even the most optimistic of predictions could not have expected it to be so over-subscribed. Stena Line has now undertaken the initial stage of the selection process and, for the first-time, is hosting two Open Days for prospective candidates on Monday th February, where they will get a chance to meet members of Stena Line’s crews. The Open Days are taking place in Belfast and Birkenhead with the latter being held onboard one of Stena Line’s newest ferries, Stena Edda, giving candidates a chance to get a first-hand taste of le onboard on the Irish Sea. Stephen Bryden, Stena Line’s Head of Onboard Sales and Services, commented on the success of the campaign: “I am astonished by the public’s response to the A Le Less Ordinary recruitment campaign. We have never received so many applications. It really goes to show how many people are attracted to a le at sea with a company like Stena Line. Now our HR team has the challenge of how to sort and interview so many applicants, but that is a nice challenge to have. Thank you to every single person that has applied to work with us.”

title: department of education strongly recommends post primary pupils to continue wearing face coverings
story: Schools will soonafter the half-term break FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSchools will soonafter the half-term breakMark BainTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Department of Education has said it’s “strongly recommended” that face coverings are worn in schools by post-primary pupils after updating guidance ahead of the end of the half-term break.Schools have now been informed that the vast majority of mitigations currently in place in educational settings remains unaffected, despite the announcement by Health Minister Robin Swann that restrictions are to be removed in wider society.The department said: “On February , , the Minister of Health informed the Assembly of his decision to move the remaining Covid restrictions into guidance. The vast majority of the DE guidance is not impacted by this and remains unchanged at this point.“The position on face coverings, based on public health advice, remains that it is strongly recommended that post-primary pupils wear a face covering at all times when inside school buildings, including classrooms, corridors and confined communal spaces such as toilet areas.“You will be aware that, by February , other UK jurisdictions will have eased their requirements for post-primary pupils to wear face coverings in schools. While our case numbers are still high, they are moving in the right direction, and the minister wishes to be in a similar position here as soon as possible. To ensure that the removal of face coverings from guidance is not delayed, the department will continue to actively engage with health colleagues to seek their most up-to-date advice, to inform the minister’s decision on this issue.“Officials will also continue to engage with practitioners and unions ahead of any change to guidance. Until any such changes are agreed, schools and educational settings should continue to implement the current Department of Education Covid guidance.”While the number of reported Covid cases among school pupils in the first week of February fell to just over ,, the figures over a -day period, since schools ed from the Christmas break, have shown a signicant rise in positive cases.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Teaching unions have voiced concerns that the removal of restrictions where will see positive case numbers rising in schools, which in turn will lead to further problems with staff absent from the classroom.“The great fear among school leaders is that the lting of restrictions will further increase the crisis of trying to find available staff and keep schools open,” said Graham Gault, interim director with the National Association of Head Teachers.“There are many across our schools feeling a bit of trepidation at what increased community transmission of coronavirus might mean for keeping schools open. What we need is to prepare for what will be asked of us.”Related topicsDepartment of EducationMore On Department of EducationTeachers ‘ready to strike’ after rejecting pay offer PremiumSchool leaders Photo: Barry BatchelorMark BainTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailMLAs have heard there are  Protestant and  Catholic primary schools less than half-a-mile from each other — with the duplication costing tens of millions of pounds every year.A consultation on a five-year area plan was recently launched by the Education Authority , with many rural schools fearing they could be closed due to falling pupil numbers and financial dficulties.Stormont’s Education Committee heard research by academics at Ulster University found  pairs of schools serving dferent sides of the community within an average  yards of each other.UU’s Unesco Education Centre’s Future Schools project has been set up to look into the sustainability of schools and provide a  for parents to have a say on education provision for their children.The research shows in  of those pairs of schools, at least one is unsustainable, according to EA criteria.The proportion of Catholics in the Controlled schools is less than %, while Maintained primaries have an average of % Catholic enrolment.The  pairs identied received an additional £.m each year, compared to the average cost to support the same pupils in combined schools in each location.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up UU’s Dr Jessica Bates told MLAs many of the problems faced by small rural schools have to be put into context.“It’s a historical position that we’re in and that’s now under review, because clearly there isn’t the right dispersal of schools in the right places,” she said.“This Future Schools project is about establishing community conversations on the ground to find out what communities would actually support.“There is little point in other people coming up with a solution unless there is going to be support for it.“Before getting to a point where someone in a management position has made a decision, there needs to be input from communities on the ground.”She admitted that, in some areas, it was very dficult to see how two schools can come together as one.And that was why the options needed to be determined by the communities themselves to help the area planning process“The rationale for this work has been the absence of any kind of engagement in previous decisions that clearly haven’t worked for local areas,” she added.She said it was “a little shocking” to hear a number of school governors say they were ill-prepared for the work they do.And she added that a Future Schools toolkit was seeking to provide them with support for self-evaluation, community engagement and a roadmap on the way forward.“What parents are telling us is that % of them have a level of concern about the future sustainability of their primary school,” she said.“Three-quarters stated there should be a merging of all under-subscribed rural schools, which would maintain primary education in their local community.“On easing school financial pressures, the themes that repeatedly came across were: merging management bodies to create one central body for managing education integration of schools the merging of under-subscribed schools the closing of unsustainable schools reducing the religious duplication of schools the sharing of specialist facilities, and creating one education system for all.“There are % of rural primary schools falling under the EA threshold of sustainability of  pupils.”Dr Bates said where this happens in a locality that would support one school, a merger can work, “but there needs to be a strong relationship between those schools, a shared education experience. Where that doesn’t exist, it’s very hard to see how a merger would be successful”.“That’s why it’s vital community discussions are enabled, and they need to be enabled before any action plans are put in place, otherwise those action plans will not be workable,” she said.“Big decisions need to be taken by managing authorities, but we want to make sure parents and communities are listened to before title: blue plaque honour for outstanding derry composer redmond friel
story: A blue plaque will be erected in Derry to commemorate Redmond FrielGetty Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA blue plaque will be erected in Derry to commemorate Redmond FrielGarrett HarganTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA blue plaque is to be unveiled in honour of Redmond Friel, a Derry man hailed as “one of the most prolic and gted” Northern Ireland composers of the th century.Musician Nuala McAllister Hart described Friel as an outstanding church musician, choral conductor and inspired arranger of Irish traditional melodies.Friel’s interest and love of Irish music spanned over  years. He passed away in  aged .A commemorative Ulster History Circle plaque will be unveiled in front of a small number of invited guests at Chapel Road Primary School where he was educated as a boy and ed to teach and became principal.Guests will include the Mayor of Derry City and Strabane Graham Warke, musician Phil Coulter, who was a pupil of Mr Friel’s, and members of the Friel family.Chris Spurr, chairman of the Ulster History Circle, said: “Redmond Friel was an outstanding composer and arranger who shared his love of music with many pupils over the years.“The Ulster History Circle is delighted to commemorate this distinguished musician with a blue plaque at the school where he achieved a unique triplet as pupil, teacher and principal.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “The Circle would like to thank Chapel Road Primary School for their assistance and Derry City and Strabane District Council for their financial support towards the plaque.”Born in February  in Duke Street, Waterside, to parents Michael Friel and Sarah Donaghey, he was introduced to Irish traditional music at a very early age.By the time Redmond had reached his teens, he could play the piano, cello, organ, clarinet and was a member of Waterside Brass and Reed Youth Band.He showed great promise as a composer and won several prizes for his compositions as a young man. To further his talents, Redmond was privately tutored in Belfast by composer, Norman Hay, a lecturer at Queen’s University.Choosing a career in education, he left Ireland to travel to London. He gained a teacher’s diploma with credits in music and maths, but decided toto his native town where he was appointed assistant teacher at the school where he had once been a pupil.His -year association with Chapel Road Primary School saw him appointed as principal in  until his final retirement in June, He also was a part-time teacher of music at St Columb’s College in Derry. Among his pupils were composer Kevin O’Connell, songwriter Paul Brady, former RTE head of music Cathal McCabe and Sean Doran, former director of the English National Opera.His major orchestral pieces include Symphonic Movement’and a ballet and concert suite on The Children of Lir, written for the Cork Ballet Festival in . In , he composed the music for the film Two Hours from London, a travelogue about Derry produced by Terence McDonald and John Hume.Most ReadMotorist lucky to be alive after tree falls on his car Credit: Martyn Boyd FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueInjection: A young child receiving a vaccination jabLisa SmythTwitterFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailHealth bosses are coming under pressure to provide better information on the safety of vaccinating young children against Covid-.It comes after a failure to address concerns about the potential long-term impact of the vaccines.Read MoreMark Bain:OpinionCovid vaccination and children: An informed choice would be more welcome than a shot in the darkThe programme is to be opened up to all children in Northern Ireland aged between five and , although a timeline and details on how it will be delivered is yet to be announced.Earlier this week, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationsaid children aged between five and  should be offered the vaccine on a non-urgent basis to help protect them in the event of a future Covid wave.However, parents are conflicted over vaccinating their young children given the relatively low risk presented by the virus, while some are worried their children may be adversely affected in years to come.And on Thursday, Northern Ireland’s Children’s Commissioner Koulla Yiasouma said she believes parents are in a dficult position.She also revealed she “doesn’t know” whether she, as a parent, would give her child the vaccine.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Speaking to the BBC’s Good Morning Ulster programme on Thursday, Ms Yiasouma said it is clear the JCVI have been “on the fence”.“The advice they issued yesterday is very ambiguous — it may be very confusing for parents,” she said.When askedshe would give the vaccine to her own childthey were in that age group, she said: “I genuinely don’t know. I have read what JCVI published.“I genuinely don’t know what I would domy children were that age. I would think very carefully. If my children were in the older age group, I would talk with them. I would also maybe have a talk with my GP and with other parents.“I was in support of the older children being vaccinated. The JCVI advice is not one way or the other.“Parents should be allowed make the decision that’s right — they shouldn’t be pilloried, they shouldn’t be attacked.”“I don’t envy parents making this decision.”While Ms Yiasouma said parents could speak to their family doctor about the issue, there are also concerns this could lead to a spike in telephone calls to already overstretched GPs.Dr Ultan Power, a professor of molecular virology at Queen’s University, said much more work is required to ensure parents can make an informed decision.“I think this is something that should be done by the Department of Health or Public Health Agencyso that parents have somewhere to go to have their questions answered,” he said.Dr Jillian Johnston, Joint Interim Assistant Director in Health Protection at the PHA, last night offered reassurances to parents, although she did not provide evidence there will be no long-term harm caused by the vaccines.“There is no evidence that the vaccine will lead to problems later in le,” she said.“As with any medicine, these vaccines are highly regulated products.“The Covid- vaccines are safe and effective and will give the best protection against coronavirus.”She continued: “The Covid- vaccine is being offered to all children aged five to  years in order to protect against severe disease and increase the immunity of vaccinated people against Covid- in advance of a potential future wave of Covid-.“While most children aged between five and  will have mild disease following infection from Covid-, some may experience symptoms which last longer than just a few days. Vaccination of children in this age group may also prevent a small number of hospitalisations and intensive care admissions, and would provide short-term protection against non-severe infection.“The impact of vaccination on future waves of Covid- is still unknown as it will depend on the characteristics of any new iants that emerge, for example timing, size and severity of infection.“While it is yet to be understood what the impact of vaccination in this age group will be on rates of infection as a whole, it is likely to provide short-term protection against illness and reduce the number of iniduals that may require admission to hospital.”Dr Johnston said the vaccines will reduce the risk of children developing paediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome .The condition can happen in some children and young people after they have had Covid- and some youngsters have already received intensive care treatment after developing PIMS.Dr Johnston explained: “The condition is a delayed reaction to the body trying to overcome the virus, and this causes swelling throughout the body.“Receiving a Covid- vaccine will help to protect children against the likelihood of developing PIMS and long Covid.“If we see a future severe wave of Covid- infection, the vaccination programme could help to prevent  hospitalisations for PIMS for every million vaccine courses delivered.”She also said children who have already had a Covid- infection will be further protectedthey are vaccinated.“While having had the virus may give you some immunity, being fully vaccinated can offer you the best protection from the virus and severe disease,” she said. “Evenyou’ve already had Covid-, you could still get it again. The vaccine will reduce your risk of another infection and the severity of symptoms.”Related topicsDepartment of HealthMore On Department of Health PremiumMark BainOpinionCovid vaccination and Credit: Tristan Morrow.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA young Kilkenny unionist has revealed that he and his family were forced to move to Northern Ireland after receiving IRA death threats.Tristan Morrowhas made headlines for creating the Irish Unionist Party . He believes the island of Ireland as a whole should become part of the UK – and in turn, separated from the EU – due to what he sees as universal economic benefits for all nations involved.The idea for his new political movement stemmed from his research of past, archetypal Irish unionists.“I then came in contact with a man from Co Clare with similar views to me,” he told the Belfast .“Quickly, we got a big group of southern people who have unionist views. Somebody said that we should start a movement over this and we thought it was a pretty good idea. We started it within the last year, maybe the year before, and we took it quite seriously.“At the moment, we haven’t been having or going to events, but so far we have  members and we should be getting a whole lot more in the coming weeks due to a new contact with the Donegal Orange Lodge. There’s massive interest in it.”But Mr Morrow’s views have led to stress and abuse towards him and other members of his group.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He added: “One of our members got sent a picture of a revolver gun and the guy said he knew where he lived and actually mentioned his house address. We quickly got that sorted by reporting it.“I have received some real-le threats from local republicans. I’m out in the countryside and whenever I’m on my walk into town and back home, I’ve had a car stop in the middle of the road and just rev at me for a good  seconds, and as they’ve driven past they#ve shouted ‘tiocfaidh ar lá’.“I#ve had to live up here in Northern Ireland for a few years now, due to my family having to move away from Kilkenny because of the IRA. I believe it was the Co Laois IRA that had decided they had enough of my family and they gave us a week to move, otherwise they#d kill us all.”Raised on a Kilkenny farm, Mr Morrow said his family is still supportive of him.“My father had saidI was going fully public about my views, that he would stand with me,” he added.He also believes the whole of Ireland should have a referendum to determine whether it would want to join or leave the UK.“In my perfect scenario, I would imagine Ireland taking part within the union sort of like how Scotland does. A united Ireland would be beneficial for both sides, but also I would like us to be united with the English economically and as one nation. I don’t see how we could not benefit from it.“And it sort of seems that the only reason people don’t want it is over tribalism. Sort of like, ‘they’re English, we don’t want to be united with the English’.”He also noted that while some members of the IUP want to remain within the EU, he would like to see Ireland follow a Brexit-like referendum.“The majority of us would like to see us out of the EU and to have more uptake into the actual world stage of economic trade, especially with the Commonwealth.“We#ve had a lot of new converts to unionism who have literally no background with it. But due to what happened in  [the financial crash], a lot of them have become outright unionists.”Mr Morrow spoke of one man from Limerick, who he said took him around dilapidated streets in the city which were once thriving with shops and businesses, but are now “rotting away”.“He was talking about how after  years, this is what all that has won us - just nothing.”Mr Morrow said that he looks “forward to what the future holds” and has welcomed the support of some like-minded unionists from Northern Ireland, including independent politicians and members of the UUP.On Wednesday, he tweeted: “Irish Unionism will be normalised in due time.If Ireland is to be united, it will only be possible through unionism heading the charge.I will always be a Kilkenny man, my family loves Kilkenny and I will never give up on my hometown.After facing some online backlash for the post, Ulster Unionist Party leader Doug Beattie replied: “Stay safe Tristan. title: new community hub approved as part of north belfasts ardoyne regeneration
story: An artist#s impression of the new Ardoyne Community Hub. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAn artist#s impression of the new Ardoyne Community Hub.Michael Kenwood, Local Democracy ReporterFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA new community hub has been approved at a former Catholic girls’ school in north Belfast’s Ardoyne.Belfast City Council’s planning committee has fully granted permission for an application by the Flax and ABC Trust to transform the now derelict St Gemma’s - closed in  - for a “community-led” mixed use regeneration scheme.It involves the demolition of the existing school buildings off Oldpark Road, and the erection of a community hub with a revised design and layout, alongside a previously approved plan for three retail units, two retail service units, and  residential units in a mix of  houses and  apartments.The wider regeneration scheme also involves the retention, refurbishment and change of use of the Flax Centre to provide business “incubation space” and education facilities, new public realm improvements along Ardoyne Avenue, the creation of a public space, and associated landscaping and car parking.At the council’s planning committee on Tuesday, elected members unanimously approved the new community hub element of the regeneration scheme.The hub building will be two storeys in height.The ground floor will comprise training rooms, a dual use area for a café event space, community offices, a gym, and a boxing ring training area, with ancillary admin offices, a foyer, and toilets.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up There will also be a secure and enclosed external courtyard area for training purposes.The first floor will comprise two flexible-use halls, changing rooms and a gym, with a multi-use sports community hall at the rear of the building.Outside there will be a hard-surfaced open event space to the front or north of the building, with a community allotment garden to the east between the building and the site boundary. Soft landscaping is proposed around the site boundaries.A total of  letters of support were received by the council, and no objections were received. title: ni rates explainer why are they rising and where is your money going
story: FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailRates in Northern Ireland council areas are set to rise in the coming financial year. However, some will rise more than others. Heres a guide to why this is the case, how rates are calculated and where the money goes.Read MoreBigger rates bills on way for all Northern Ireland householdsHow are rates calculated Rates are made up of two parts: the regional rate and the district rate. The regional rate is set by Stormont and, along with the block grant from the Treasury, pays for the likes of schools, health and roads. The district rate is set by your local council and pays for services that the council is responsible for, such as refuse collection, leisure provision and street cleaning.Finance Minister Conor Murphy has frozen the regional rate for the coming financial year, due to the lingering impact of the pandemic and the current poor financial climate.District rates are either domesticor non-domestic . While councils have the power to set dferent rates increases for households and businesses, this year all councils have chosen to instead set one percentage increase for both. Domestic and non-domestic rates are calculated by multiplying the rateable valuation of your home business by the combined district and regional rate.Domestic and non-domestic rates are set in terms of the number of pence in each pound of the value of your home business. For instance, in the Newry, Mourne and Down council area, the domestic rate for the   financial year is . pence, while the non-domestic rate will be . pence.!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Why are rates increasing, and why are they rising in some areas more than others There are several factors that councils have to take into account when setting their district rate, including cost of living, inflation, the council#s own financial reserves and other income, and the wider economic outlook.Last year, several councils chose to freeze their rates due to the impact of the pandemic, dipping into their reserves to absorb the loss of income. Others chose to raise their rates slightly, however this has meant playing a degree of catch-up this year, when all councils have opted to hike their rates.Some councils may be able to mitigate the rise through other savings, while those local authorities which are in a more financially healthy state, can strike a lower rate and use their savings to make up for the loss.Where does the money go As mentioned, district rates pay for services the council is responsible for. Many councils also increase rates with an eye on using some of the revenue for particular projects.Ards and North Down council, for instance, has said the money for the coming financial year will go towards redeveloping Bangor Waterfront and creating an #innovation hub#, while in Belfast some revenue will go towards supporting the development of office accommodation, hotels and retail as part of city centre development. In Fermanagh and Omagh, the council said the rates will raise around £m in extra revenue, £m of which is to be set aside for waste management.Related topicsBelfast City CouncilArds and North Down title: sinn feins hargey writing to other stormont ministers in hope of unlocking stadium funding
story: Sinn Fein#s Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey. Credit: Brian Lawless PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein#s Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey. Credit: Brian Lawless PA WireChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailCommunities Minister Deirdre Hargey has confirmed she will write to other Stormont ministers in a bid to progress funding for football stadiums across Northern Ireland.Ms Hargey told the BBC she would  be writing to her fellow ministers to seethe funding could be released, despite the absence of a fully ing Northern Ireland Executive.Earlier on Thursday, Northern Ireland football chiefs welcomed assurances they had received from the minister that a £m commitment to local stadiums remains in place.The funding package due to be distributed to clubs across Northern Ireland was a commitment the government made  years ago and it was then reaffirmed in the ‘New Decade, New Approach’ document in .However, Ms Hargey announced the Executive is unable to sign off the £m after the resignation of the DUP’s Paul Givan.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreDavid Jeffrey: Irish League helped Northern Ireland through dark days of the Troubles and Covid… give us our £.m stadia fundingGraham Luney:OpinionIrish League is being treated with contempt and fans have had enough of Stormont’s blame game… do your jobs and release stadia fundingIrish League clubs to join forces at Windsor Park meeting in bid to force Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey to release £m Stadia Funding“The money’s there, the money’s on the table. We need to find a way of unlocking that money without the Executive,” she said.Ms Hargey confirmed she has met officials in both the Irish Football Association and Northern Ireland Football League to discuss the matter after criticism of her decision by the bodies and clubs across the province.Following the meeting she said: “I welcomed the opportunity to reaffirm my commitment and intention to deliver this much needed scheme which will benefit football at all levels.“Today I have met with representatives of IFA and NIFL and together we will work to progress this project to the next stage.”The NIFL welcomed her statement of intent after what they called a “dficult week”.NIFL CEO Gerard Lawlor stated: “I welcome the minister’s response to our concerns this afternoon.We held an open and frank discussion and we received assurances: the programme will proceed as planned, acknowledgment that an increase on the m is required and is being sought, and the programme remains a flagship project for the Executive.Communication is key in the delivery of this programme going forward and I hope to see it delivered in a timely manner”.The DUP has sought to portray the comments of Ms Hargey as a u-turn.The party’s deputy leader accused Ms Hargey of attempting to “play sectarian politics” with the issue.“The Minister has had two years to deliver the funding.“Indeed, last September she told us it was just weeks away,” Paula Bradley said.“It’s time for Minister Hargey to set her Sinn Fein political games to the side and get on with her job and deliver the funding.”Earlier it was revealed Steven Mills, Chief Operating Officer at NIFL, has invited a representative from each club to a special meeting at Windsor Park on Monday, kicking off at pm.Ms Hargey has claimed that while the funding has been secured for the initiative, the approval of the wider Executive is required before it can progress to allocating funding for projects at specic grounds.She has blamed the DUP for the situation, claiming the party’s decision to pull Paul Givan out of the first minister’s role meant the stadia programme had to be placed on hold until a ing administration is back in place.The DUP has disputed this position and contrasted it with the minister’s insistence that the redevelopment of the GAA’s Casement Park in west Belfast can continue despite the Stormont crisis.On Thursday, a spokesperson for the Department for Communities said: “The Minster has been clear that the .m to regenerate stadiums is ring fenced.“The Minister is absolutely committed to delivering this investment to support clubs and build first class facilities.“It is well known that options for the future of the sub regional stadia programme requires Executive approval.“The collapse of the Executive is preventing the regeneration of local stadiums.“The Minister is exploring all options available in the current situation.“Today the Minister held a meeting with representatives of the IFA and NIFL and agreed to work together to progress this project to the next stage.”Related topicsDeirdre HargeyDepartment for CommunitiesMore On Deirdre HargeyIrish League Credit: Liam McBurneySuzanne BreenTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailColum Eastwood has accused Sinn Fein of focusing on selfish party interests rather than improving the lives of ordinary people.The SDLP leader said his rival’s -year record in government was abysmal, and while the party had engaged in radical rhetoric, it had failed to deliver.Speaking ahead of his party’s annual conference this weekend, Mr Eastwood said that despite lacklustre poll ratings, the SDLP hoped to secure two ministries in the next Executive.However, he refused rule out going into oppositionhe didn’t believe that it would be “a government truly working for the people”.In a wide-ranging interview, he described Doug Beattie as “a breath of fresh air within unionism”. While he was aghast at the UUP leader’s tweets, he respected how he had faced up to his mistakes, taken the heat and opened himself up to scrutiny in media interviews.Mr Eastwood also said he had no regrets about using parliamentary privilege to name Soldier F, who faced murder charges for his actions on Bloody Sunday.He said he was “giving a voice” to the people of Derry in a House of Commons that desperately needs to hear views from Northern Ireland other than the DUP’s.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Despite at times sharing similar policies with Sinn Fein, Mr Eastwood insisted the parties were in practice very dferent.“Sinn Fein are interested in themselves alone. They’re focused on what benefits them as a party, what improves their position, securing community jobs for their mates,” he said.“They’ve been at the top in Stormont since  and have failed to change the lives of working-class communities despite having their hands on the levers of power.“After  years, you’ve had your chance. Those who don’t deliver should be punished at the ballot box. “Sinn Fein are not outsiders. With the DUP, they are the political establishment in the North.”Mr Eastwood was unimpressed with Sinn Fein’s performance in the current Executive: “They talk a lot, but don’t seem to do much. What have they actually achieved “Nichola Mallon and Robin Swann have been the outstanding ministers in the Executive. I don’t see too many others that have done much.”The SDLP leader accused the DUP of pursuing a “destructive and unbelievably foolish course of action”y.He expects his party to improve on its  seats and % vote in the  Assembly election. He is hoping it will secure a similar vote to its  Westminster result of %.“We would hope to gain enough seats to have two ministers in the next executive,” Mr Eastwood said.“We are running to be in government. It’s in our DNA to be in government.”But he said he could not rule out going into opposition “ we think it’s a government that will do nothing for the people”.On just % in this week’s Irish News Institute of Irish Studies of University of Liverpool poll, the SDLP seems to have a steep hill to climbit is tomore MLAs. Successive LucidTalk polls for the Belfasthave put the party in fourth or fth position.“I think that too much attention is given to polls in Northern Ireland,” Mr Eastwood said“As a deeply ided society, it’s one of the hardest places to poll. You have five political parties within  to % of each other, so it’s complicated.“We are not blind to polls, but neither are we worried about them. We do our own research and we’re confident that we’re not on %.”Mr Eastwood said the DUP’s decision to collapse the Executive had polarised the political environment in a way that suited Sir Jeffrey Donaldson’s party and Sinn Fein.But the SDLP leader predicted it would not be a “pro- or anti-protocol” election.“In my office in Derry, people aren’t talking about the protocol. They’re worried about bills and hospital waiting lists. They’re annoyed at sluggish government.“There has been no response to the cost of living crisis by Stormont. In Scotland, the government is putting money into people’s bank accounts. Ours is doing nothing.”The SDLP leader said that in some constituencies, his party would be battling with Sir Jeffrey Donaldson’s for the last seat, “and that will create a dynamic which helps us”.He cited Strangford as its best chance of a gain, followed by Fermanagh and South Tyrone and West Belfast, “while there’s an outside chance we will be in the mix at the end in South Antrim”.The SDLP faces a tough battle to retain its seats in three constituencies. However, Mr Eastwood was “very confident” Pat Catney would be re-elected in Lagan Valley he said Dolores Kelly should “never be written off” in Upper Bann and he believed his party had “enough votes to keep our two seats in South Down”.The SDLP leader said he wouldn’t be advising voters who to transfer to. “There’ll be dferent considerations in dferent constituencies,” he said. He would like people “to vote progressively and for change”.AskedSDLP supporters should transfer to unionist candidates he said: “If a candidate is progressive, then there shouldn’t be community barriers to giving them a preference. In the polling booth, I have and will transfer across the community ide.”In the wake of Doug Beattie’s tweet scandal, Mr Eastwood said he had “failed the leadership test”.Askedthe UUP leader should have resigned, he replied: “What Doug did was wrong and dficult to understand, but there was something very powerful in his ability to face up to his mistakes and to take the heat.“I think in those circumstances, people are ready to forgive. I certainly don’t agree with Doug on everything, but I like him. I think he’s coming at things from a good place. He’s a breath of fresh air for unionism.”Mr Eastwood said it had been “very important” for him to name Soldier F in the Commons.“The Bloody Sunday families wanted him outed and I wanted my constituents’ voices heard,” he explained.“I received numerous death threats for it, some more sinister than others. That’s fine for me, but it was hard for my family.“I didn’t believe anything would happen to them, but you still worry when you’re away from home at nights.”Mr Eastwood insisted that his party had influence at Westminster: “Claire Hanna and I are not going to overturn an -seat majority, but it’s vital that we — along with Stephen Farry — are there and it’s not just the DUP being heard.”He said that would particularly be the casean Executive could not be formed after May’s election and direct rule was reintroduced.The potential partnership with Fianna Fail, which Mr Eastwood had championed, is clearly now dead in the water for the SDLP.  Asked about the possibility, he would say only that he was “in regular contact” with Fianna Fail and that the shared island unit had “come out of our conversations” with Micheal Martin.Claire Hanna had strongly opposed any merger. Effectively acknowledging it was totally off the agenda now, Mr Eastwood stressed: “The SDLP stands on its own two feet.“We’ve moved beyond old arguments. I work very well with Claire Hanna at Westminster and she’s part of the leadership team.”The SDLP leader also categorically ruled out ever personally seeking a dual mandate.
